questions.text: A patient with frontotemporal dementia shows features like apathy, disinhibition, compulsivity, and overeating. The coronal MRI is shown with lesions labeled with white arrow heads. Which clinical core syndrome FTD is it?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Behavioral variant (bvFTD) The patient has a typical clinical finding of behavioral frontotemporal dementia . An MRI shows anterior atrophy , spreading to the orbital and prefrontal cortex .

Highyeild:

FTD variant ( FrontoTemporalDementia) Degeneration with atrophy occurs in Findings Behavioral FTD The medial and orbital frontal and anterior insula Apathy Disinhibition Compulsivity Loss of empathy Overeating Deficits in executive control. Semantic variant PPA The anterior temporal region Slowly lose the ability to decode word, object, person-specific, and emotional meaning. Nonfluent /agrammatic PPA primary progressive aphasia (PPA) The lateral frontal and precentral gyrus of the dominant hemisphere Inability to produce words Prominent motor speech impairment.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B, C, and D will have different clinical and MRI-brain

questions.text: Neuropathology in frontotemporal lobar degeneration shows the following. What is the finding:

options.label: A
options.text: Small compact or crescentic neuronal cytoplasmic inclusions and short, thin neuropil threads in FTLD-TDP, type A

options.label: B
options.text: Diffuse/granular neuronal cytoplasmic inclusions (with a relative paucity of neuropil threads) in FTLD-TDP, type B

options.label: C
options.text: Long, tortuous dystrophic neurites in FTLD-TDP, type C

questions.correct_answer: A. Small compact or crescentic neuronal cytoplasmic inclusions and short, thin neuropil threads in FTLD-TDP, type A
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Small compact or crescentic neuronal cytoplasmic inclusions and short, thin neuropil threads in FTLD-TDP, type A

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B, C, and D have different immunohistochemistry findings.

questions.text: Identify the neuro pathological finding in frontotemporal lobar degeneration shown in the Image below:

options.label: A
options.text: Tufted astrocyte in progressive supranuclear palsy

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intraneuronal cytoplasmic inclusions (Pick bodies)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, C, D have different immunohistochemistry findings.

questions.text: 45-year-old Mr. Bhattad presents to the hospital with a movement disorder and behavioral disturbance. For the past month, he has been having frequent, sudden, jerky and irregular movements of his upper extremities. He has become irritable, and does not visit his family or friends. He is a business executive, and co-workers have commented on the serious decline in his performance. His father had similar problems and died in a nursing home. A CT scan is ordered. Which of the following is a typical CT finding in such patients?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atrophy of caudate nucleus This patient has both movement (chorea) and behavioral disorder i.e., impaired executive function early in the course of disease, along with irritability and positive family history of similar complaints suggests Huntington’s disease. Atrophy of the caudate nucleus is a characteristic feature , and is seen on neuroimaging as enlargement of lateral ventricles. (Boxcar ventricle)

Highyeild:

HUNTINGTON’S DISEASE - Autosomal dominant Chromosome 4 Trinucleotide:CAG amplification (>40) Anticipation( an earlier onset than the parent.) Neurotransmitter abnormalities- Decreased Acetylcholine Decreased GABA Increased Dopamine Motor problems- Chorea/Athetosis/Tremor(hallmark) Features - Dementia Oculomotor dysfunction Cognitive deficit Behavior abnormalities Agitation Psychosis Chorea/Athetosis/Tremor→ progress to Bradykinesia MRI- Caudate atrophy Box car ventricle Treatment- Motor features Dopamine depleters e.g. Tetrabenazine Psychosis Atypical antipsychotics Nonmotor manifestations SSRI Benzodiazepines

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Diffuse atrophy of the cerebral cortex is a feature of Alzheimer’s disease. It’s a disease of old age. Option: C and D . Atrophy of the frontal and/or temporal lobes is a feature of Pick's disease .no history of inappropriate behavior/ compulsion provided in question.

Extraedge:

Huntington’s disease. FLAIR-MRI shows enlargement of the lateral ventricles reflecting typical atrophy of the head of the caudate nucleus (arrows). Axial FLAIR image demonstrates abnormal high signal in the caudate and putamen (arrows)

questions.text: A 47-year-old obese female comes to the office for the evaluation of recent episodes of mood instability. Her mood varies between sad and irritable. She denies any other symptoms, except for some mild forgetfulness She tearfully shares that she is convinced that she is going to die, as her father also developed similar symptoms around the same age and died subsequently. On physical examination, writhing movements of the extremities are prominent .This patient's clinical presentation is most consistent with ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Huntington’s disease This patient has both movement (chorea) and behavioral disorder i.e.impaired executive function early in the course of disease,along with mood instability , agitation and positive family history of similar complaints suggests Huntington’s disease.

Highyeild:

HUNTINGTON’S DISEASE - Autosomal dominant Chromosome 4 Trinucleotide:CAG amplification (>40) Anticipation( an earlier onset than the parent.) Neurotransmitter abnormalities- Decreased Acetylcholine Decreased GABA Increased Dopamine Motor problems- Chorea/Athetosis/Tremor(hallmark) Features - Dementia Oculomotor dysfunction Cognitive deficit Behavior abnormalities Agitation Psychosis Chorea/Athetosis/Tremor→ progress to Bradykinesia MRI- Caudate atrophy Box car ventricle Treatment- Motor features Dopamine depleters E.g. Tetrabenazine Psychosis Atypical antipsychotics Nonmotor manifestations SSRI Benzodiazepines

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: Option: A. Alzheimer’s disease. It’s a disease of old age. Option: B. Pseudodementia -Severe depression in the elderly can present with dementia similar to Alzheimer's disorder. However, such patients usually do not have any associated motor manifestations . Option: D. Hypothyroidism -This patient's obesity, mood symptoms and dementia make hypothyroidism a possible diagnosis; however, movement disorders are unlikely in patients with hypothyroidism .

Extraedge:

Huntington’s disease. A.FLAIR-MRI shows enlargement of the lateral ventricles reflecting typical atrophy of the head of the caudate nucleus (arrows). B.Axial FLAIR image demonstrates abnormal high signal in the caudate and putamen (arrows)

questions.text: Which of the following most closely correlates with the age of symptom onset with Huntington disease?

options.label: B
options.text: Specific base pair affected by individual point mutation

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Triplet repeat length The length of the triplet repeat in the Huntingtin gene is associated with the age of symptom onset . Further, the triplet repeat length increases over subsequent generations, leading to earlier disease onset . This phenomenon is known as genetic anticipation.

Highyeild:

HUNTINGTON’S DISEASE - Autosomal dominant Chromosome 4 Trinucleotide:CAG amplification (>40) Anticipation( an earlier onset than the parent.) Neurotransmitter abnormalities- Decreased Acetylcholine Decreased GABA Increased Dopamine Motor problems- Chorea/Athetosis/Tremor(hallmark) Features - Dementia Oculomotor dysfunction Cognitive deficit Behavior abnormalities Agitation Psychosis Chorea/Athetosis/Tremor→ progress to Bradykinesia MRI- Caudate atrophy Box car ventricle Treatment- Motor features Dopamine depleters e.g. Tetrabenazine Psychosis Atypical antipsychotics Nonmotor manifestations SSRI Benzodiazepines

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Specific base pair affected by individual point mutation-Huntington’s disease is a specific CAG triplet repeat , not a point mutation. Option: C. Gender of affected parent -Neither the gender of the patient nor of the affected parent (parental imprinting) affects symptom onset in Huntington's disease. Option: D. Parental age of symptom onset- may provide a rough guide for a patient, but genetic anticipation means that the patient will generally have an earlier onset than the parent.

questions.text: A 33-year-old Mrs. Smitha presents with an inability to sit still and difficulty sleeping, which have developed gradually over 3 years. On examination, there are subtle choreiform movements involving both the trunk and the distal upper extremities. She also has delayed initiation of saccades, as well as tongue impersistence. She is adopted, but knows that her mother committed suicide after years of abusing drugs. Her magnetic resonance image (MRI) is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Huntington disease As patient has chorea, oculomotor dysfunction, agitation and MRI shows Boxcar ventricle, Caudate atrophy.

Highyeild:

HUNTINGTON’S DISEASE - Autosomal dominant Chromosome 4 Trinucleotide:CAG amplification (>40) Anticipation( an earlier onset than the parent.) Neurotransmitter abnormalities- Decreased Acetylcholine Decreased GABA Increased Dopamine Motor problems- Chorea/Athetosis/Tremor(hallmark) Features - Dementia Oculomotor dysfunction Cognitive deficit Behavior abnormalities Agitation Psychosis Chorea/Athetosis/Tremor→ progress to Bradykinesia MRI- Caudate atrophy Box car ventricle Treatment- Motor features Dopamine depleters e.g. Tetrabenazine Psychosis Atypical antipsychotics Nonmotor manifestations SSRI Benzodiazepines

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Sydenham chorea- There is nothing in the question stem indicating a recent streptococcal infection. Option: C. Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis- has been associated with chorea , but would not show an absence of caudate nuclei. Option: D. A stroke of the subthalamic nucleus -can also lead to choreiform movements, but the onset is usually acute and leads to unilateral chorea

Extraedge:

Huntington’s disease. FLAIR-MRI shows enlargement of the lateral ventricles reflecting typical atrophy of the head of the caudate nucleus (arrows). Axial FLAIR image demonstrates abnormal high signal in the caudate and putamen (arrows)

questions.text: Which of the following neurodegenerative conditions caused the pathological findings seen in the figure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Huntington disease The image demonstrates atrophy of the caudate , with so-called boxcar ventricles , which is characteristic of Huntington's disease.

Highyeild:

Huntington’s disease. A.FLAIR-MRI shows enlargement of the lateral ventricles reflecting typical atrophy of the head of the caudate nucleus (arrows). B.Axial FLAIR image demonstrates abnormal high signal in the caudate and putamen (arrows)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Alzheimer disease- may show atrophy of the mesial temporal lobe and temporoparietal junction. Option: B. Pick disease- would show frontal atrophy. Option: C. Parkinson disease- would show loss of pigmented neurons in the substantia nigra.

questions.text: Which of the following medications would not be indicated in the treatment of Huntington's disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carbidopa/levodopa The treatment of the motor features of Huntington’s disease (and other hyperkinetic movement disorders) is typically aimed at reducing dopaminergic action. Levodopa contains dopamine, so it is not helpful in Huntington’s disease.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Dopamine depleters- E.g tetrabenazine works by inhibiting the vesicular monoamine transporter (VMAT) protein , thereby decreasing dopamine, useful in treating motor symptoms. Option: B. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs): Both SSRIs and benzodiazepines are aimed at treating the nonmotor manifestations of obsessive-compulsive disorder tendencies, anxiety, and insomnia . Option D. Antipsychotics - block dopamine’s action at the D2 receptor so it can be used to treat psychosis in Huntington’s disease .

questions.text: 67-year-old Mr. Khan comes to hospital with his wife due to increasing difficulty performing his job over the past year. He has become more irritable at work, has acted inappropriately, and has gotten into arguments with his boss for the first time in 20 years. His office has become increasingly cluttered as he refuses to throw things out, and he has not submitted numerous assignments. His wife echoes similar concerns in his home life and describes him as withdrawn, emotionally detached, and "not the man I married." In addition, the patient eats only certain foods and is less interested in his appearance. The patient scores 25/30 on the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (normal > 26). Which of the following is most likely to be diagnosed in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Frontotemporal dementia This patient's symptoms and course of illness are most consistent with the behavioral variant of frontotemporal dementia (FTD), as he has early personality ( withdrawn, emotionally detached, and "not the man I married."), behavioral changes Acted inappropriately gotten into arguments with his boss) and compulsive behaviors (e.g., hoarding, hyperorality) and executive dysfunction .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: Dementia with Lewy bodies -presents as visual hallucinations, parkinsonism, REM sleep behavior disorder, and fluctuating cognition . Option: Hoarding disorder- will have inability to dispose of items that may have no actual worth (eg, magazines, paper towels), resulting in significant and often dangerous physical clutter in the home environment. Personality changes and cognitive impairment in this patient make this unlikely. Option: Major depressive disorder- may show withdrawn, apathetic behavior and reversible cognitive impairment, this patient lacks other key features of depression (eg, sadness, feelings of worthlessness, feeling of hopelessness) . His symptom constellation and marked change in personality are better explained by Frontotemporal dementia (FTD).

Extraedge:

TAU pathies α-Synuclein FrontoTemporalDisease(FTD) Parkinson disease Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) Lewy body dementia Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) Multiple system atrophy(MSA)

questions.text: A 63-year-old Mr. Tobu presents to the clinic with memory problems. Over the last several months he developed problems with his speech. He frequently calls objects by the wrong name or cannot come up with the words he wants to say. His neurological examination is normal, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of his brain shows temporal lobe atrophy. On mental status examination he is alert and oriented. His speech is clear and he can repeat, but he has difficulty with naming objects. He frequently replaces words with either nonsensical words or the wrong words. He is able to remember three words in 3 minutes, draw intersecting pentagons, and draw a clock accurately. In 1 minute he was only able to name four animals. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Primary progressive aphasia This patient has Anomic aphasia ,word deficiency (used nonsensical/wrong words) with intact memory and orientation.

Highyeild:

Primary progressive aphasia- Patient presents with normal memory and orientation but has paraphasia Memory and visuospatial function should be normal. It is a subclass of frontotemporal dementia that involves progressive loss of speech to the point of mutism. Early in the disease this disorder may not be appreciated unless testing of verbal fluency is performed, including categorical fluency (naming as many animals as possible in 1 minute, or naming as many words starting with the letter “S” as possible in 1 minute or more formal testing like the Boston Naming Test.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: Alzheimer disease- would present with short-term memory loss and visuospatial dysfunction , in addition to anomic aphasia. Option: Dementia with Lewy bodies- presents with well-formed visual hallucinations, fluctuating levels of alertness, memory loss, and parkinsonism. Option: D. Vascular dementia -is the second most common type of dementia and results from cerebral ischemia, usually progressing in a stepwise fashion , related to either large or small infarcts. This often results in poor short-term memory .The MRI shows multiple ischemic lesions.

Extraedge:

TAU pathies α-Synuclein FrontoTemporalDisease(FTD) Parkinson disease Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) Lewy body dementia Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) Multiple system atrophy(MSA)

questions.text: In neuropsychological testing, a pathological lack of motivation not from a mood disorder results from a lesion to which circuit ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anterior cingulate gyrus The anterior cingulate gyrus has a role in motivation . The anterior cingulate cortex and adjacent medial prefrontal cortex project to the nucleus accumbens and interruption of this system produces apathy, poverty of speech, emotional blunting , or even akinetic mutism . This is common in frontotemporal dementia, Alzheimer disease, Huntington disease, and even depression.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Dorsolateral prefrontal cortex Lesions or of either the caudate or their connecting white matter pathways , may result in executive dysfunction, manifesting as poor organization and planning, decreased cognitive flexibility, and impaired working memory. Option: B. The lateral orbitofrontal cortex - controls Impulsivity . Option: D. The Papez circuit -involves the hippocampus, mammillary bodies, anterior thalamic nuclei, and the cingulate gyrus .primarily in the cortical control of emotion and memory storage and contains centers that regulate aversion and gratification.

questions.text: A 53 year old woman is brought to the hospital by her husband for follow-up evaluation of behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia, which was diagnosed 9 months ago. Her clinical symptoms of occasional aphasia, minor memory impairment, behavioral disinhibition and obsessive compulsive behaviors have worsened since diagnosis. She was asked to leave the house as she recently brought a trash can from neighbors on her granddaughter's 2nd birthday. Her husband asks about possible medications to control her symptoms . Which among the following is the most appropriate medication to recommend ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Citalopram The Patient is a known case of Behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia. This patient's obsessive tendencies have not only have had embarrassing consequences but have also resulted in a confrontation with family members. The treatment of behavioral FTD is symptom based and should target most troubling manifestations . This patient should be given SSRI to control her obsessive compulsive behaviors .

Highyeild:

Management of Behavioral variant Frontotemporal dementia- Trazodone+SSRI Used for agitation,depression,compulsivity,restlessness. Lithium Used for agitation Atypical antipsychotic Used for delusions and hallucinations Oxytocin Improves Apathy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Donepezil - is approved for Alzheimer disease and evidence does not support its use in Behavioural FTD Option: C. Memantine- is approved for moderate to severe Alzheimer disease and have no benefit in FTD in fact it can worsen it Option: D. Atypical antipsychotics- are not FDA approved for this clinical indication as it increases cerebrovascular events and mortality in dementia patients . If delusions and hallucinations present only then olanzapine should be considered.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is referred to the neurologist for evaluation of EEG abnormalities. He initially presented with rapidly progressive dementia and behavioral abnormalities. He has no history of seizures or head trauma. The physical examination revealed a myoclonus. An extensive work-up has been unrevealing; however, the EEG report revealed sharp , triphasic, and synchronous discharges. Which of the following abnormalities is most likely in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Defect in an autosomal dominant gene on chromosome 4

options.label: D
options.text: Neurodegeneration of frontal and temporal lobes

questions.correct_answer: B. Spongiform encephalopathy caused by prion
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spongiform encephalopathy caused by prion This patient's presentation is classic for Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. The typical features, as stated above include rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, and sharp, triphasic,synchronous discharges on EGG It is a spongiform encephalopathy caused by a prion.

Highyeild:

CREUTZFELDT JAKOB DISEASE- Prion disease Pathology Spongiform encephalopathy Astrocyte -gliosis No inflammation Subtypes Sporadic CJD Most common Familial CJD Fatal familial insomnia GSS(Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker disease) Variant CJD On eating contaminant food Iatrogenic CJD Due to contaminated instrument use Clinical features- RAPIDLY PROGRESSIVE DEMENTIA Weight loss.anxiety,sleep disorder Behavior anomalies Visual hallucinations Depression Intellectual Judgment Organization skills Memory /speech/visuospatial Abolia Akinetic mutism-Stupor MYOCLONIC SEIZURE (Startle response)>90%of CJD On EEG Generalized periodic(1/sec) Biphasic/triphasic wave On MRI Cortical ribboning Basal ganglia enhancement Variant CJD Pulvinar sign On CSF 14.5.3 elevated Normal cell count No specific treatment.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Defect in an autosomal dominant gene on chromosome 4 -Causes Huntington's dementia. Option: C. Loss of nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons- Causes Parkinson disease. Option: D. Neurodegeneration of frontal and temporal lobes -causes Frontotemporal dementias .

Extraedge:

Clinical differentiation of the major dementias DISEASE FIRST SYMPTOM MENTAL STATUS NEUROPSYCHIATRY NEUROLOGY IMAGING AD Memory loss Episodic memory loss Irritability, anxiety, depression Initially normal Entorhinal cortex and hippocampal atrophy FTD Apathy, poor judgment/ insight, speech/language, hyperorality Frontal/executive and/or language; spares drawing Apathy, disinhibition, overeating, compulsivity May have vertical gaze palsy, axial rigidity, dystonia, alien hand, or MND Parkinsonism Frontal, insular, and/or temporal atrophy; usually spares posterior parietal lobe DLB Visual hallucinations, REM sleep behavior disorder, delirium, Capgras syndrome, parkinsonism Drawing and frontal/ executive, spares memory, delirium-prone Visual hallucinations, depression, sleep disorder, delusions Parkinsonism Posterior parietal atrophy, hippocampi larger than in ADI CJD Dementia, mood, anxiety, movement disorders Variable, frontal/ executive, focal cortical, memory Depression, anxiety, psychosis in some Myoclonus, rigidity, parkinsonism Cortical ribboning and basal ganglia or thalamus hyperintensity on diffusion/ FLAIR MRI Vascular Often but not always sudden, variable, apathy, falls, focal weakness Frontal/executive, cognitive slowing, can spare memory Apathy, delusions, anxiety Usually motor slowing, spasticity, can be normal Cortical and/or subcortical infarctions, confluent white matter disease Abbreviations: AD, Alzheimer's disease; CBD, cortical basal degeneration; CJD, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease; DLB, dementia with Lewy bodies; FLAIR, fluid-attenuated inversion recovery; FTD, frontotemporal dementia; MND, motor neuron disease; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; REM, rapid eye movement.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the hospital due to worsening insomnia, confusion, and memory loss over the past 3 weeks. He also has muscle twitching and gait problems and this has caused several falls. He has no fever, headache, or urinary problems. He does not use alcohol or tobacco. His vitals are stable. He is poorly groomed and disoriented to date and time. He has cognitive impairment . The NCCT head is normal with characteristic spongiform changes. The EEG shows periodic sharp waves. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease The patient has rapid progressive dementia , along with sleep disorder, muscle twitching ( myoclonic jerks) , behavioral abnormality, abulia (poorly groomed). NCCT shows spongiform changes; EEG shows periodic sharp waves; all this points towards Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

Highyeild:

CREUTZFELDT JAKOB DISEASE- Prion disease Pathology Spongiform encephalopathy Astrocyte -gliosis No inflammation Subtypes Sporadic CJD Most common Familial CJD Fatal familial insomnia GSS(Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker disease) Variant CJD On eating contaminant food Iatrogenic CJD Due to contaminated instrument use Clinical features- RAPIDLY PROGRESSIVE DEMENTIA Weight loss.anxiety,sleep disorder Behavior anomalies Visual hallucinations Depression Intellectual Judgment Organization skills Memory /speech/visuospatial Abolia Akinetic mutism-Stupor MYOCLONIC SEIZURE (Startle response)>90%of CJD On EEG Generalized periodic(1/sec) Biphasic/triphasic wave On MRI Cortical ribboning Basal ganglia enhancement Variant CJD Pulvinar sign On CSF 14.5.3 elevated Normal cell count No specific treatment.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Normal pressure hydrocephalus : Patients will have triad of gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and cognitive impairment with ventricular enlargement on CT scan. Option: C. Lewy body dementia- will present with parkinsonism, waxing and waning alertness, and visual hallucinations. Option: D. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, causes muscle atrophy . Clinical signs include hyperreflexia , fasciculations, spasticity, and weakness ; myoclonus is not typically seen.

Extraedge:

Clinical differentiation of the major dementias DISEASE FIRST SYMPTOM MENTAL STATUS NEUROPSYCHIATRY NEUROLOGY IMAGING AD Memory loss Episodic memory loss Irritability, anxiety, depression Initially normal Entorhinal cortex and hippocampal atrophy FTD Apathy, poor judgment/ insight, speech/language, hyperorality Frontal/executive and/or language; spares drawing Apathy, disinhibition, overeating, compulsivity May have vertical gaze palsy, axial rigidity, dystonia, alien hand, or MND Parkinsonism Frontal, insular, and/or temporal atrophy; usually spares posterior parietal lobe DLB Visual hallucinations, REM sleep behavior disorder, delirium, Capgras syndrome, parkinsonism Drawing and frontal/ executive, spares memory, delirium-prone Visual hallucinations, depression, sleep disorder, delusions Parkinsonism Posterior parietal atrophy, hippocampi larger than in ADI CJD Dementia, mood, anxiety, movement disorders Variable, frontal/ executive, focal cortical, memory Depression, anxiety, psychosis in some Myoclonus, rigidity, parkinsonism Cortical ribboning and basal ganglia or thalamus hyperintensity on diffusion/ FLAIR MRI Vascular Often but not always sudden, variable, apathy, falls, focal weakness Frontal/executive, cognitive slowing, can spare memory Apathy, delusions, anxiety Usually motor slowing, spasticity, can be normal Cortical and/or subcortical infarctions, confluent white matter disease Abbreviations: AD, Alzheimer's disease; CBD, cortical basal degeneration; CJD, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease; DLB, dementia with Lewy bodies; FLAIR, fluid-attenuated inversion recovery; FTD, frontotemporal dementia; MND, motor neuron disease; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; REM, rapid eye movement.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female has presented with memory loss over the last several weeks. A magnetic resonance image is obtained, and a diffusion weighted image is displayed here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease The patient has rapid progressive dementia,restricted diffusion to the grey matter, and cortical ribboning.

Highyeild:

CREUTZFELDT JAKOB DISEASE- Prion disease Pathology Spongiform encephalopathy Astrocyte -gliosis No inflammation Subtypes Sporadic CJD Most common Familial CJD Fatal familial insomnia GSS(Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker disease) Variant CJD On eating contaminant food Iatrogenic CJD Due to contaminated instrument use Clinical features- RAPIDLY PROGRESSIVE DEMENTIA Weight loss.anxiety,sleep disorder Behavior anomalies Visual hallucinations Depression Intellectual Judgment Organization skills Memory /speech/visuospatial Abolia Akinetic mutism-Stupor MYOCLONIC SEIZURE (Startle response)>90%of CJD On EEG Generalized periodic(1/sec) Biphasic/triphasic wave On MRI Cortical ribboning Basal ganglia enhancement Variant CJD Pulvinar sign On CSF 14.5.3 elevated Normal cell count No specific treatment.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: Option A, B, and D - Frontotemporal dementia, Huntington disease, and Alzheimer disease- do not cause restricted diffusion.

Extraedge:

Other potential causes of cortical ribboning: Anoxic injury Cortical stroke Postictal state Herpes simplex Virus encephalitis Meningoencephalitis Genetic conditions- Mitochondrial myopathy Encephalopathy Acidosis with stroke-like episodes.

questions.text: Which of the following is different between the prion protein PrPc associated with sporadic Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and the normal prion protein PrPSc?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Three-dimensional structure The difference between the prion protein PrPc associated with sporadic Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and the normal prion protein PrPSc is the three-dimensional folding.

Highyeild:

Several different scenarios might explain the initiation of sporadic prion disease: A somatic mutation -the mutant PrPSc must be capable of targeting wild-type PrPC, a process known to be possible for some mutations but less likely for others. The activation energy barrier separating wild-type PrPC from PrPSc could be crossed on rare occasions when viewed in the context of a population. Most individuals would be spared, but presentations in older people, with an incidence of 1 per million, would be seen. PrPSc may be present at low levels in some normal cells , where it performs an important, but as yet unknown, function. The level of PrPSc in such cells is hypothesized to be sufficiently low as not to be detected by routine bioassay. In some altered metabolic states , the cellular mechanisms for clearing PrPSc might become compromised , and the rate of PrPSc formation would then begin to exceed the capacity of the cell to clear it. It suggests that PrPSc is not simply a misfolded protein , as proposed for the first and second mechanisms, but that it is an alternatively folded molecule with a function . Moreover, the multitude of conformational states that PrPSc can adopt, as described above, raises the possibility that PrPSc or another protein might function in a process such as short-term memory, where information storage is thought to occur in the absence of new protein synthesis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A , C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 65-year-old, obese, female comes to the office for the evaluation of her progressively worsening memory. She lives alone. The development of her new symptoms is causing her some distress, as she often forgets to pay her bills. A detailed review of the systems reveals no other symptoms, except for mild urinary incontinence. An abdominal examination shows no tenderness or masses. Neurological examination shows a broad-based, shuffling gait and a right-sided carotid bruit. A complete blood count and serum chemistry panel are within normal limits. MRI shows significantly enlarged ventricles. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus The patient has a triad of symptoms: normal pressure hydrocephalus , d ementia (very slow and progressive memory impairment), g ait disturbance (broad-based, shuffling gait) and (mild) urinary incontinence. MRI shows dilated ventricles, confirming the same. Carotid bruit indicates turbulent blood flow pointing towards some obstructive cause that led to initial obstructive hydrocephalus , a transient increase in intracranial pressure , ventricular enlargement , and the pressure returning to normal . Normal pressure hydrocephalus

Highyeild:

NORMAL PRESSURE HYDROCEPHALUS - No papilledema On imaging Enlarged ventricles Clinical feature Triad Dementia Ataxia Urinary incontinence Magnetic gait Treatment Large volume CSF tap Gait improves V-P shunt(Ventriculoperitoneal shunt)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Alzheimer’s disease: Except for diffuse atrophy, MRI is normal in patients with Alzheimer's disease. They usually do not have problems with gait or urinary incontinence. Option: B. Pseudotumor cerebri - is seen in young, obese females and presents with headaches , not memory impairment. Shrunken ventricles may be seen on an MRI . Option: D. Parkinsonism: This patient's shuffling gait and memory deterioration may suggest the diagnosis of Parkinsonism . However, her urinary incontinence and MRI suggest normal pressure hydrocephalus as the most likely diagnosis.

Extraedge:

Clinical differentiation of the major dementias DISEASE FIRST SYMPTOM MENTAL STATUS NEUROPSYCHIATRY NEUROLOGY IMAGING AD Memory loss Episodic memory loss Irritability, anxiety, depression Initially normal Entorhinal cortex and hippocampal atrophy FTD Apathy, poor judgment/ insight, speech/language, hyperorality Frontal/executive and/or language; spares drawing Apathy, disinhibition, overeating, compulsivity May have vertical gaze palsy, axial rigidity, dystonia, alien hand, or MND Parkinsonism Frontal, insular, and/or temporal atrophy; usually spares posterior parietal lobe DLB Visual hallucinations, REM sleep behavior disorder, delirium, Capgras syndrome, parkinsonism Drawing and frontal/ executive, spares memory, delirium-prone Visual hallucinations, depression, sleep disorder, delusions Parkinsonism Posterior parietal atrophy, hippocampi larger than in ADI CJD Dementia, mood, anxiety, movement disorders Variable, frontal/ executive, focal cortical, memory Depression, anxiety, psychosis in some Myoclonus, rigidity, parkinsonism Cortical ribboning and basal ganglia or thalamus hyperintensity on diffusion/ FLAIR MRI Vascular Often but not always sudden, variable, apathy, falls, focal weakness Frontal/executive, cognitive slowing, can spare memory Apathy, delusions, anxiety Usually motor slowing, spasticity, can be normal Cortical and/or subcortical infarctions, confluent white matter disease Abbreviations: AD, Alzheimer's disease; CBD, cortical basal degeneration; CJD, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease; DLB, dementia with Lewy bodies; FLAIR, fluid-attenuated inversion recovery; FTD, frontotemporal dementia; MND, motor neuron disease; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; REM, rapid eye movement.

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman, Mrs. Malhotra, presents to her primary care physician complaining of memory loss. She reports increasing difficulty balancing her checquebook and remembering the names of new acquaintances over the last several months. Her only other complaint is occasional urinary incontinence, which she attributes to old age. On exams, her vital signs were within normal limits. The heart and lung exams are also unremarkable. The cranial nerves are intact, the fundoscopic exam is normal, and no tremor is observed. Her gait is slow and shuffling; there is no dysmetria; and her MMSE is 24/30. A CT scan of her brain is shown below. Which of the following interventions is most likely to relieve her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ventriculoperitoneal shunt This woman has the classic symptom triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus, abnormal gait ( slow and shuffling) , urinary incontinence and dementia (increasing difficulty balancing her chequebook and remembering the names of new acquaintances) with enlarged ventricles seen on CT plus no papilledema . 30–50% of patients with NPH (Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus) will improve with ventricular shunting.

Highyeild:

NORMAL PRESSURE HYDROCEPHALUS - No papilledema On imaging Enlarged ventricles Clinical feature Triad Dementia Ataxia Urinary incontinence Magnetic gait Treatment Large volume CSF tap Gait improves V-P shunt(Ventriculoperitoneal shunt)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Vitamin B12 Replacement: Vitamin B12 deficiency is a potentially reversible cause of dementia , but it is unlikely to cause incontinence. Option: B. Levodopa/carbidopa -Parkinson's disease and NPH may present similarly, but patients with Parkinson's are much more likely to have tremor and less likely to have early incontinence or dementia . Unlike Parkinson's disease, NPH does not respond to levodopa or carbidopa Option: D. Hematoma evacuation- is the treatment of choice for large or symptomatic epidural or subdural hematomas. This patient's CT scan shows no hematoma.

questions.text: 76-year-old Mr. Ashok presents with several months of urinary incontinence He denies associated dysuria, nocturia, or penile discharge, and has otherwise been feeling well aside from moderate left arm pain following a fall three days ago. He denies a headache or head trauma. On examination, his vital signs were within normal limits. DTRs are normal and have no muscle weakness. His gait is wide based and shuffling, and he scores 24/30 on the MMSE. What is the most likely cause of his current Condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decreased CSF absorption This patient has the classic symptom triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) : abnormal gait (wide based and shuffling), urinary incontinence , and dementia (24/30 on the MMSE).

Highyeild:

NORMAL PRESSURE HYDROCEPHALUS - NPH is a clinical syndrome accompanied by increased ventricular size without persistent elevations in intracranial pressure . Symptoms result from distortion of the periventricular brain matter . The prevailing theory for the pathogenesis of NPH is Initial obstructive hydrocephalus or diminished CSF absorption at the arachnoid villi ; transient increase in intracranial pressure ; ventricular enlargement ; the pressure returns to normal . Normal pressure hydrocephalus

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: Increased CSF production: CSF production tends to increase at night , but increases in CSF production are not strongly associated with a particular disease process. Option B: Spinal cord compression is associated with muscle weakness and hyperactive deep tendon reflexes. Option D: Amyloid proteins deposit in the brain and underlies Alzheimer's disease. Most affected patients present with cognitive deficits. Incontinence is a late feature.

questions.text: Patient with Normal pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH). Which among the following statements are correct :- a) MRI shows ventriculomegaly with caudate atrophy b) CSF tap test will improve the symptoms c) Triad of ataxia, Urinary incontinence and dementia d) Ventriculoperitoneal shunt will improve the symptoms Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

b,c,d are correct The clinical triad includes ataxia ,dementia and urinary incontinence. MRI shows ventriculomegaly. CSF tap/ Ventriculoperitoneal shunt will improve the symptoms.

Highyeild:

NORMAL PRESSURE HYDROCEPHALUS - No papilledema On imaging Enlarged ventricles Clinical feature Triad Dementia Ataxia Urinary incontinence Magnetic gait Treatment Large volume CSF tap Gait improves V-P shunt(Ventriculoperitoneal shunt)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Statement A: Caudate atrophy is seen in Huntington’s disease. Option A, C, and D are incorrect.

Extraedge:

A transient improvement in gait or cognition may follow lumbar puncture (or serial punctures ) with the removal of 30–50 mL of CSF . The most reliable strategy is a period of close inpatient evaluation before, during, and after lumbar CSF drainage. 30 to 50 % of patients identified by careful diagnosis as having NPH will improve with ventricular shunting . Gait may improve more than cognition, but many reported failures to improve cognitively may have resulted from comorbid AD .

questions.text: A 60-year-old man receives a corneal transplant from a donor who died from a mysterious, rapidly progressive dementia. About six months after his vision is restored, he begins to suffer cognitive decline. A magnetic resonance image (MRI) of the brain is obtained and shown here. Based on the underlying diagnosis, which of the following is most likely to be seen on a brain biopsy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spongiform changes with vacuolization The patient likely has iatrogenic Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) , a prion disease that leads to rapidly progressive dementia due to contaminated corneal transplant. The MRI pictured has classic fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) hyperintensity in the thalamus (pulvinar sign). Pathologically, CJD is known for spongiform changes and extensive vacuolization, especially in the cortex and deep grey matter.

Highyeild:

CREUTZFELDT JAKOB DISEASE- Prion disease Pathology Spongiform encephalopathy Astrocyte -gliosis No inflammation Subtypes Sporadic CJD Most common Familial CJD Fatal familial insomnia GSS(Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker disease) Variant CJD On eating contaminant food Iatrogenic CJD Due to contaminated instrument use Clinical features- RAPIDLY PROGRESSIVE DEMENTIA Weight loss.anxiety,sleep disorder Behavior anomalies Visual hallucinations Depression Intellectual Judgment Organization skills Memory /speech/visuospatial Abolia Akinetic mutism-Stupor MYOCLONIC SEIZURE (Startle response)>90%of CJD On EEG Generalized periodic(1/sec) Biphasic/triphasic wave On MRI Cortical ribboning Basal ganglia enhancement Variant CJD Pulvinar sign On CSF 14.5.3 elevated Normal cell count No specific treatment.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: Reactive gliosis Option B: Negri bodies are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion bodies seen in rabies encephalitis. Option C: Cowdry type A bodies - are eosinophilic nuclear inclusions seen in herpes infection

questions.text: 72-year-old Mrs. Chopra is brought to the hospital by her daughter due to a change in behavior. Over the past three months, the patient has become more withdrawn. She no longer watches her favourite television shows and seems less interested in her family. The daughter has noticed increasing forgetfulness over the past three years but assumed it "comes with ageing " Over the past year, the patient has stopped doing the daily crossword, and had difficulty remembering to eat and clean herself. Which of the following tests is not required ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CSF analysis The patient's symptoms are consistent with those of dementia. The choice of laboratory tests in the evaluation of dementia is complex and should be tailored to the individual patient. Lumbar punctures need not be done routinely in the evaluation of dementia .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, B, and D . The American Academy of neurology recommends the routine assessment of CBC , Electrolytes, TSH , Vit B12 level and neuroimaging in all patients suspected of having dementia and to treat reversible causes.

questions.text: Which among the following are potentially reversible causes of dementia? a) Normal pressure hydrocephalus b) Depression c) Nicotinic acid deficiency d) Binswanger’s disease Choose the correct answer from below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a,b,c are correct Binswanger’s disease is a small-vessel ischemic disease. Vascular dementia is irreversible dementia.

Highyeild:

Binswanger’s disease (subcortical arteriosclerotic encephalopathy)- Prototypical clinical syndrome with gradual cognitive deterioration and notable white matter changes of small-vessel ischemic disease On neuroimaging, a progressive confluent subcortical and periventricular white matter disease is seen with hypoperfusion and hypometabolism .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Statement: a) normal pressure hydrocephalus; b) Depression; c) nicotinic acid deficiency are reversible causes of Option B, C ,and D are incorrect.

Extraedge:

Deficiency of nicotinic acid (pellagra)- is associated with skin rashes over sun-exposed areas, glossitis, and angular stomatitis . A severe dietary deficiency of nicotinic acid along with other B vitamins such as pyridoxine may result in spastic paraparesis, peripheral neuropathy, fatigue, irritability, and dementia.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about the course of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)?

options.label: A
options.text: Rapidly progressive dementia as well as motor abnormalities

options.label: B
options.text: Generally causes death after 10 years of onset

options.label: C
options.text: Most CJD patients are between 50 and 75 years of age

options.label: D
options.text: Progress over weeks or months to a state of profound dementia

questions.correct_answer: B. Generally causes death after 10 years of onset
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Generally causes death after 10 years of onset The illness is rapidly progressive and generally causes death within nine months of onset. CJD typically presents with rapidly progressive dementia as well as motor abnormalities. Most CJD patients are between 50 and 75 years of age; however, patients as young as 17 and as old as 83 have been recorded. always progresses over weeks or months to a state of profound dementia characterized by memory loss, impaired judgment, and a decline in virtually all aspects of intellectual function.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, C, and D are correct.

questions.text: 60/male develops depression, rapidly progressive mental deterioration, and ataxia. His wife tells you that he "jumps out of the chair" when the door is slammed. A CSF examination reveals increased levels of the pathognomic protein. Over the next six months, condition deteriorated, and died 2 months later. Diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Creutzfeldt Jakob Disease The clinical vignette points towards CJD. Points in favor are - Rapidly progressive mental deterioration Characteristic startle response Elevated CSF protein ( 14-3-3 ) Rapidly deteriorating clinical course and death.

Highyeild:

CREUTZFELDT JAKOB DISEASE- Prion disease Pathology Spongiform encephalopathy Astrocyte -gliosis No inflammation Subtypes Sporadic CJD Most common Familial CJD Fatal familial insomnia GSS(Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker disease) Variant CJD On eating contaminant food Iatrogenic CJD Due to contaminated instrument use Clinical features- RAPIDLY PROGRESSIVE DEMENTIA Weight loss.anxiety,sleep disorder Behavior anomalies Visual hallucinations Depression Intellectual Judgment Organization skills Memory /speech/visuospatial Abolia Akinetic mutism-Stupor MYOCLONIC SEIZURE (Startle response)>90%of CJD On EEG Generalized periodic(1/sec) Biphasic/triphasic wave On MRI Cortical ribboning Basal ganglia enhancement Variant CJD Pulvinar sign On CSF 14.5.3 elevated Normal cell count No specific treatment.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: SSPE- is incorrect since no h/s/o childhood measles and also SSPE occurs usually in the adolescent age group. No characteristic CSF protein is seen Option C: PML -is incorrect. Even though the s/s are similar, but PML usually seen in immunocompromised host Option D: Rapidly deteriorating clinical course -is incorrect as it is a non-specific choice.

questions.text: 60/male develops depression, rapidly progressive mental deterioration, and ataxia. He is diagnosed as CJD. All of the following statements are true regarding this except?

options.label: D
options.text: Hereditary variant due to PRNP gene on 20th chromosome

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Presence of inflammatory response CREUTZFELDT JAKOB DISEASE does not show inflammation Hereditary variants due to the PRNP gene o n the 20th chromosome will have AD familial CJD.

Highyeild:

CREUTZFELDT JAKOB DISEASE- Prion disease Pathology Spongiform encephalopathy Astrocyte -gliosis No inflammation Subtypes Sporadic CJD Most common Familial CJD Fatal familial insomnia GSS(Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker disease) Variant CJD On eating contaminant food Iatrogenic CJD Due to contaminated instrument use Clinical features- RAPIDLY PROGRESSIVE DEMENTIA Weight loss.anxiety,sleep disorder Behavior anomalies Visual hallucinations Depression Intellectual Judgment Organization skills Memory /speech/visuospatial Abolia Akinetic mutism-Stupor MYOCLONIC SEIZURE (Startle response)>90%of CJD On EEG Generalized periodic(1/sec) Biphasic/triphasic wave On MRI Cortical ribboning Basal ganglia enhancement Variant CJD Pulvinar sign On CSF 14.5.3 elevated Normal cell count No specific treatment.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male was brought to the OPD by his wife with poor memory, progressive vision deterioration, and strange nature of suddenly jumping out from the chair when the door is suddenly closed shut. O/E diffuse myoclonus is present. CSF shows an increase of 14-3-3. Over the next 6 months, the condition of the patient deteriorated, and the patient died two months later. On autopsy, spongiform degeneration is noted in the brain. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sporadic CJD Patient has dementia, startle response,myoclonus on examination, and increase in CSF protein 14-3-3 , spongiform degeneration and rapid deterioration and death point towards CJD (Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease) . with age of patient between 60-70 years and no significant dietary/family/Iatrogenic history provided in the question suggests Sporadic CJD.

Highyeild:

Sporadic CJD- Age of presentation- around 60-70 yrs Death within 6-12 months. Several different scenarios might explain the initiation of sporadic prion disease A somatic mutation -the mutant PrPSc must be capable of targeting wild-type PrPC, a process known to be possible for some mutations but less likely for others. The activation energy barrier separating wild-type PrPC from PrPSc could be crossed on rare occasions when viewed in the context of a population. Most individuals would be spared, but presentations in older persons, with an incidence of 1 per million, would be seen. PrPSc may be present at low levels in some normal cells , where it performs an important, but as yet unknown, function. The level of PrPSc in such cells is hypothesized to be sufficiently low as not to be detected by routine bioassay. In some altered metabolic states , the cellular mechanisms for clearing PrPSc might become compromised , and the rate of PrPSc formation would then begin to exceed the capacity of the cell to clear it. It suggests that PrPSc is not simply a misfolded protein , as proposed for the first and second mechanisms, but that it is an alternatively folded molecule with a function . Moreover, the multitude of conformational states that PrPSc can adopt, as described above, raises the possibility that PrPSc or another protein might function in a process such as short term memory where information storage is thought to occur in the absence of new protein synthesis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: FamilialCJD - No familial history given. Option C: VariantCJD - No history of consuming sheep in diet or cannibalism provided in question. Option D: IatrogenicCJD - Accidental transmission of CJD to humans appears to have occurred with corneal transplantation , contaminated electroencephalogram (EEG) electrode implantation, and surgical procedures which are not provided in question.

questions.text: 40/Male was brought to the medicine OPD with c/o poor memory, depression and progressive mental deterioration. Family members have noticed a strange nature of suddenly jumping out of a chair whenever a loud sound is made. Past history is significant for corneal transplant secondary to corneal degeneration a few years back. O/E myoclonus present. CSF confirms the diagnosis. Most likely diagnosis would be?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Iatrogenic CJD Patient has Progressive mental deterioration,Startle response( sudden jumping from chair on loud sound) with myoclonus on examination suggests CJD (Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease) with history of corneal transplant point towards Iatrogenic CJD.

Highyeild:

Iatrogenic CJD Age of presentation - not specific Etiology -Accidental transmission of CJD to humans with contaminated corneal transplantation electroencephalogram (EEG) electrode implantation surgical instruments dura grafts human pituitary derived gonadotropins. Death within - 6-12 months. Some might live for 5 years.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Sporadic CJD - The precise cause of sporadic CJD is unclear, but it's been suggested that a normal brain protein changes abnormally ("misfolds") and turns into a Most cases of sporadic CJD occur in adults aged between 45 and 75 . Option: B. Familial CJD - No familial history given Option: C. Variant CJD -No history of consuming sheep in diet or cannibalism provided in question.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male belonging to the tribal population known for cannibalism is brought to the OPD with progressive mental deterioration, talking irrelevant and sometimes muttering to himself. symptoms started a few months back. No significant past and family history. However several others from that tribe had similar c/o in this age group and none of them could survive beyond 1-2 yrs. O/E myoclonus present. Rhomberg's test positive. Psychiatric opinion taken ivo mental changes and psychiatry opinion comes as Acute psychosis. Condition of the patient keeps deteriorating over next 8 months and he dies 6 months thereafter. Most likely diagnosis would be?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Variant CJD Patient has Rapidly progressive dementia,Behavior anomalies with Myoclonus on examination suggest CJD (Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease) with history of cannibalism (Human meat consumption) and similar complaints in the same community point towards Variant CJD.

Highyeild:

Variant CJD The restricted geographic occurrence and chronology of vCJD raised the possibility that BSE prions (bovine spongiform encephalopathy) had been transmitted to humans through the consumption of tainted beef. What is certain is that PrP-prion-tainted meat should be prevented from entering the human food supply. The most compelling evidence that vCJD is caused by BSE prions was obtained from experiments in mice expressing the bovine PrP transgene . Both BSE and vCJD prions were efficiently transmitted to these transgenic mice and with similar incubation periods. In contrast to sCJD prions , vCJD prions did not transmit disease efficiently to mice expressing a chimeric human–mouse PrP transgene. Earlier studies with nontransgenic mice suggested that vCJD and BSE might be derived from the same source because both inocula transmitted disease with similar but very long incubation periods. Attempts to determine the origin of BSE and vCJD prions have relied on passing studies in mice, some of which are described above, as well as studies of the conformation and glycosylation of PrPSc. One scenario suggests that a particular conformation of bovine PrPSc was selected for heat resistance during the rendering process and was then reselected multiple times as cattle infected by ingesting prion-contaminated meat and bone meal (MBM) were slaughtered and their offal rendered into more MBM. Variant CJD cases have virtually disappeared with protection of the beef supply.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: Sporadic CJD- The precise cause of sporadic CJD is unclear, but it's been suggested that a normal brain protein changes abnormally ("misfolds") and turns into a Most cases of sporadic CJD occur in adults aged between 45 and 75 . Option B: Familial CJD - No familial history given Option D: Iatrogenic CJD - Accidental transmission of CJD to humans appears to have occurred with corneal transplantation, contaminated electroencephalogram (EEG) electrode implantation , and surgical procedures.

questions.text: 48/Male is brought to the OPD with c/o rapidly progressive mental deterioration, depression and ataxia. His wife says that her husband often jumps out of the chair when the door is slammed. CSF confirms the diagnosis. No significant past history. Family history is significant for similar presentations in his father and grandfather at an early age around 45-50 yrs. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Familial CJD Patient has rapidly progressive mental deterioration, depression and ataxia with Startle response suggests CJD (Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease) Family history is present.

Highyeild:

Familial CJD More than 40 different mutations resulting in nonconservative substitutions in the human PRNP gene have been found to segregate with inherited human prion diseases. Missense mutations, a deletion, and expansions in the octapeptide repeat region of the gene , called octapeptide repeat insertions (OPRIs) , are responsible for genetic forms of prion disease . Although phenotypes may vary dramatically, even within families, specific phenotypes observed with certain mutations appear to cause sCJD

Option: C. VariantCJD No history of consuming sheep in diet or cannibalism provided in question. Option D. IatrogenicCJD - Accidental transmission of CJD to humans appears to have occurred with corneal transplantation, contaminated electroencephalogram (EEG) electrode implantation, and surgical procedures .
